snippet: Francis’ march to the papacy began with the meetings of cardinals that occurred before the conclave. His remarks struck a chord, but he held on to a low profile.
abstract: Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio won the papacy, according to comments from cardinals, Vatican experts and leaks to Italian newspapers, in part because the Vatican-based cardinals  were intent on protecting their bureaucracy; they snubbed presumptive front-runner, and a favored candidate of reformers, Cardinal Angelo Scola; Pope Francis' attractive mix of piety, humility and administrative skills won over many cardinals.

byline.contributor: Elisabetta Povoledo and Rachel Donadio contributed reporting.

lead_paragraph: Francis’ march to the papacy began with the meetings of cardinals that occurred before the conclave. His remarks struck a chord, but he held on to a low profile.

headline.seo: New Pope’s Piety and Humility Aided His Surprise Selection
headline.main: Snub of Reformers’ Choice Seen Before Pope’s Anointing
headline.print_headline: Choice of Pope Said to Follow Snubbing of Reform Favorite
